ingredients.title: Ingredients
ingredients.description: This section provides detailed information about various non-alcoholic ingredients used in the bar and bartending industry. It includes juices, fruits, herbs, vegetables, dairy products, sodas, ice, and garnishes, detailing their uses, origins, and specific characteristics.

subsections.title: Juices
subsections.description: Juices are fundamental ingredients in cocktails and other beverages, providing flavor, sweetness, and acidity. This section covers various types of juices, their best uses, and tips for freshness.

types.name: Citrus Juices
types.description: Citrus juices are commonly used in cocktails for their bright, tangy flavors and acidity. They are essential in many classic cocktails and are often used fresh for the best flavor.

examples.name: Lemon Juice
examples.origin: Lemon trees are believed to have originated in Asia, particularly India and China.
uses: Classic cocktails such as the Whiskey Sour and Tom Collins.
As a souring agent in culinary dishes.
To balance sweetness in various drinks.
examples.best_used_fresh: For optimal flavor and acidity, use freshly squeezed lemon juice rather than bottled.

examples.name: Lime Juice
examples.origin: Limes are believed to have originated in Southeast Asia.
uses: Key ingredient in cocktails like the Margarita and Daiquiri.
As a tangy addition to salsas and marinades.
To add acidity and brightness to mixed drinks.
examples.best_used_fresh: Freshly squeezed lime juice provides the best flavor and acidity.

examples.name: Orange Juice
examples.origin: Oranges are thought to have originated in Southeast Asia.
uses: Popular in cocktails like the Mimosa and Screwdriver.
As a base for tropical drinks and smoothies.
To add sweetness and citrus flavor to various beverages.
examples.best_used_fresh: Freshly squeezed orange juice is preferred for its vibrant flavor and reduced oxidation.

types.name: Berry Juices
types.description: Berry juices are used for their rich flavors and colors, adding complexity and visual appeal to cocktails.

examples.name: Cranberry Juice
examples.origin: Cranberries are native to North America.
uses: Essential in cocktails like the Cosmopolitan and Sea Breeze.
As a tart ingredient in culinary dishes and sauces.
To add a vibrant red color and tangy flavor to drinks.
examples.best_used_fresh: Fresh cranberry juice is often preferred for its sharp flavor and health benefits.

examples.name: Raspberry Juice
examples.origin: Raspberries are native to Europe and North America.
uses: Used in cocktails like the Raspberry Mojito and Raspberry Martini.
As a sweet and tart ingredient in desserts and sauces.
To add a rich, fruity flavor to beverages.
examples.best_used_fresh: Fresh raspberry juice provides a more intense flavor and color.

types.name: Vegetable Juices
types.description: Vegetable juices are used for their unique flavors and health benefits, often used in savory cocktails and mocktails.

examples.name: Tomato Juice
examples.origin: Tomatoes are native to western South America.
uses: Key ingredient in cocktails like the Bloody Mary.
As a base for savory drinks and soups.
To add depth and umami to mixed drinks.
examples.best_used_fresh: Freshly made tomato juice is preferred for its vibrant flavor and nutritional benefits.

examples.name: Carrot Juice
examples.origin: Carrots are believed to have originated in Persia (modern-day Iran and Afghanistan).
uses: Used in cocktails like the Carrot Margarita.
As a sweet and earthy addition to smoothies and juices.
To add a natural sweetness and rich color to drinks.
examples.best_used_fresh: Fresh carrot juice provides the most flavor and nutrients.

subsections.title: Fruits
subsections.description: Fruits are a versatile ingredient in cocktails, providing sweetness, acidity, and flavor. This section covers various fruits used in beverages, including their origins, sugar content, and usage.

types.name: Citrus Fruits
types.description: Citrus fruits are widely used for their tangy flavor and high acidity. They are essential in many cocktails and often used fresh.

examples.name: Lemon
examples.origin: Lemons are believed to have originated in Asia, particularly India and China.
uses: Used in cocktails like the Lemon Drop Martini and Lemonade.
As a garnish and flavor enhancer in a variety of drinks.
In culinary applications for its acidic flavor.

examples.name: Lime
examples.origin: Limes are believed to have originated in Southeast Asia.
uses: Essential in cocktails like the Margarita and Mojito.
To add a tangy flavor to a variety of beverages and dishes.
As a garnish and in flavored syrups.

examples.name: Orange
examples.origin: Oranges are thought to have originated in Southeast Asia.
uses: Used in cocktails like the Screwdriver and Mimosa.
In juices, smoothies, and as a garnish.
In various culinary dishes and sauces.

types.name: Berries
types.description: Berries are used for their vibrant colors and rich flavors, adding both sweetness and tartness to cocktails.

examples.name: Strawberry
examples.origin: Strawberries are native to Europe and North America.
uses: In cocktails like the Strawberry Daiquiri and Strawberry Mojito.
As a garnish and in syrups.
In desserts and fruit salads.

examples.name: Raspberry
examples.origin: Raspberries are native to Europe and North America.
uses: Used in cocktails like the Raspberry Martini and Raspberry Mojito.
In syrups, sauces, and desserts.
As a garnish and in mixed drinks.

types.name: Tropical Fruits
types.description: Tropical fruits bring exotic flavors and sweetness to cocktails, often used in both fresh and juiced forms.

examples.name: Pineapple
examples.origin: Pineapples are native to South America, particularly Brazil and Paraguay.
uses: In cocktails like the Pi√±a Colada and Mai Tai.
As a fresh fruit in tropical drinks and garnishes.
In syrups and fruit salads.

examples.name: Mango
examples.origin: Mangoes are believed to have originated in South Asia.
uses: In cocktails like the Mango Margarita and Mango Daiquiri.
As a fresh fruit in smoothies and fruit salads.
In syrups and flavored spirits.

subsections.title: Herbs
subsections.description: Herbs add fresh and aromatic flavors to cocktails and other beverages. They are used for their distinctive tastes and often as garnishes.

types.name: Mint
types.description: Mint is widely used for its refreshing flavor and aromatic qualities, commonly found in many classic cocktails.

examples.name: Spearmint
examples.origin: Spearmint is native to Europe and Asia.
uses: In cocktails like the Mojito and Mint Julep.
As a garnish and in fresh syrups.
In culinary dishes for added freshness.

examples.name: Peppermint
examples.origin: Peppermint is native to Europe and the Middle East.
uses: In cocktails like the Peppermint Martini and Mint Mojito.
As a garnish and in liqueurs.
In culinary applications for a strong mint flavor.

types.name: Basil
types.description: Basil provides a sweet and slightly spicy flavor, often used in cocktails for its unique taste.

examples.name: Sweet Basil
examples.origin: Sweet Basil is native to India and other parts of Asia.
uses: In cocktails like the Basil Smash and in flavored syrups.
As a garnish in fresh cocktails and dishes.
In culinary applications for its aromatic flavor.

types.name: Rosemary
types.description: Rosemary adds a pine-like flavor and aromatic quality to cocktails, often used in both fresh and infused forms.

examples.name: Rosemary
examples.origin: Rosemary is native to the Mediterranean region.
uses: In cocktails like the Rosemary Gin Fizz and Rosemary Mule.
As a garnish and in infused syrups.
In culinary applications for its aromatic qualities.

subsections.title: Vegetables
subsections.description: Vegetables are used in cocktails and beverages for their unique flavors and health benefits. They are often juiced or used fresh.

types.name: Cucumbers
types.description: Cucumbers provide a crisp, refreshing flavor and are commonly used in both cocktails and mocktails.

examples.name: Cucumber
examples.origin: Cucumbers are believed to have originated in India.
uses: In cocktails like the Cucumber Cooler and Cucumber Gin Fizz.
As a garnish and in infused waters.
In culinary applications for its refreshing taste.

types.name: Celery
types.description: Celery adds a crisp, mildly peppery flavor to cocktails and is often used as a garnish or juice.

examples.name: Celery
examples.origin: Celery is believed to have originated in the Mediterranean region.
uses: In cocktails like the Bloody Mary and Celery Gimlet.
As a garnish and in savory drinks.
In culinary dishes for its crunchy texture.

subsections.title: Dairy
subsections.description: Dairy products are used in cocktails and other beverages for their creamy texture and rich flavor. They are often used in both traditional and innovative drinks.

types.name: Milk
types.description: Milk is used in a variety of cocktails for its creamy texture and neutral flavor.

examples.name: Whole Milk
examples.origin: Whole milk is derived from cows and has been consumed globally.
uses: In cocktails like the White Russian and Creamsicle Martini.
As a base for creamy beverages and milkshakes.
In culinary applications for its rich texture.

examples.name: Almond Milk
examples.origin: Almond milk is made from almonds and is a popular dairy alternative.
uses: In cocktails like the Almond Joy Martini and in dairy-free drinks.
As a substitute for dairy milk in various beverages and recipes.
In smoothies and desserts for a nutty flavor.

types.name: Cream
types.description: Cream adds a rich, smooth texture to cocktails, often used in both sweet and savory drinks.

examples.name: Heavy Cream
examples.origin: Heavy cream is derived from the fatty part of milk.
uses: In cocktails like the Brandy Alexander and Irish Coffee.
As a base for creamy liqueurs and desserts.
In culinary applications for its richness and texture.

subsections.title: Sodas
subsections.description: Sodas are carbonated beverages that add fizz and flavor to cocktails. They are often used as mixers or enjoyed on their own.

types.name: Club Soda
types.description: Club soda is carbonated water with added minerals, used as a mixer in cocktails for its neutral flavor and effervescence.

examples.name: Schweppes Club Soda
examples.origin: A well-known brand of club soda, originating in the UK.
uses: In cocktails like the Tom Collins and Gin and Tonic.
As a mixer for various drinks and to add effervescence.

types.name: Tonic Water
types.description: Tonic water is carbonated water with added quinine and sweeteners, providing a distinctive bitter flavor.

examples.name: Fever-Tree Tonic Water
examples.origin: A premium tonic water brand known for its high-quality ingredients.
uses: In cocktails like the Gin and Tonic.
As a mixer to add a bitter flavor to drinks.

types.name: Ginger Ale
types.description: Ginger ale is a carbonated soft drink flavored with ginger, providing a spicy and sweet flavor.

examples.name: Canada Dry Ginger Ale
examples.origin: A popular brand of ginger ale originating in Canada.
uses: In cocktails like the Moscow Mule and Dark 'n' Stormy.
As a mixer and a refreshing beverage on its own.

subsections.title: Ice
subsections.description: Ice is used to chill and dilute cocktails, affecting both the temperature and texture of drinks.

types.name: Cubed Ice
types.description: Cubed ice is the most common form of ice used in cocktails, providing a consistent cooling effect.

examples.name: Standard Ice Cubes
uses: In a wide range of cocktails to chill and dilute the drink.
As a base for ice buckets and coolers.

types.name: Crushed Ice
types.description: Crushed ice is used for its ability to chill drinks quickly and its texture, which can be ideal for certain cocktails.

examples.name: Crushed Ice
uses: In cocktails like the Mint Julep and Mai Tai.
For slushy or frozen drinks.

subsections.title: Garnishes
subsections.description: Garnishes are decorative elements used to enhance the presentation and flavor of cocktails. They can include fruits, herbs, and other items.

types.name: Citrus Peels
types.description: Citrus peels are often used as a garnish for their aromatic qualities and visual appeal.

examples.name: Lemon Peel
uses: In cocktails like the Martini and Old Fashioned.
To add a fresh citrus aroma and a hint of flavor.

examples.name: Orange Peel
uses: In cocktails like the Negroni and Manhattan.
To provide a fragrant citrus aroma and a touch of bitterness.

types.name: Herb Sprigs
types.description: Herb sprigs add a fresh, aromatic touch to cocktails, enhancing both appearance and flavor.

examples.name: Mint Sprig
uses: In cocktails like the Mojito and Mint Julep.
As a garnish to add freshness and visual appeal.

examples.name: Rosemary Sprig
uses: In cocktails like the Rosemary Mule and Gin Fizz.
To add a pine-like aroma and a decorative element.

types.name: Edible Flowers
types.description: Edible flowers are used for their vibrant colors and delicate flavors, adding a decorative touch to cocktails.

examples.name: Violets
uses: In cocktails like the Violet Martini.
To add a pop of color and a subtle floral note.

examples.name: Elderflowers
uses: In cocktails like the Elderflower Collins.
For their delicate floral aroma and flavor.
